name: Improper Verification of Intent by Broadcast Receiver
description: The Android application uses a Broadcast Receiver that receives an Intent but does not properly verify that the Intent came from an authorized source.
extended_description: Certain types of Intents, identified by action string, can only be broadcast by the operating system itself, not by third-party applications. However, when an application registers to receive these implicit system intents, it is also registered to receive any explicit intents. While a malicious application cannot send an implicit system intent, it can send an explicit intent to the target application, which may assume that any received intent is a valid implicit system intent and not an explicit intent from another application. This may lead to unintended behavior.

common_consequences.note: Another application can impersonate the operating system and cause the software to perform an unintended action.

description: Before acting on the Intent, check the Intent Action to make sure it matches the expected System action.

demonstrative_examples.text:
<Intro_Text>The following example demonstrates the weakness.</Intro_Text>
               <Example_Code Nature="bad" Language="XML">
                  <xhtml:div><manifest package="com.example.vulnerableApplication"><xhtml:div style="margin-left:10px;">
                        <xhtml:div><application><xhtml:br/>
                           <xhtml:i>...</xhtml:i>
                           <xhtml:br/>
                           <xhtml:div style="margin-left:10px;">
                              <xhtml:div><receiver android:name=".ShutdownReceiver"><xhtml:div style="margin-left:10px;"><intent-filter><xhtml:div style="margin-left:10px;"><action android:name="android.intent.action.ACTION_SHUTDOWN" /></xhtml:div></intent-filter></xhtml:div></receiver></xhtml:div>
                           </xhtml:div>
                           <xhtml:br/>
                           <xhtml:i>...</xhtml:i>
                           <xhtml:br/>
                           <xhtml:br/></application></xhtml:div>
                     </xhtml:div></manifest></xhtml:div>
               </Example_Code>
               <Body_Text>The ShutdownReceiver class will handle the intent:</Body_Text>
               <Example_Code Nature="bad" Language="Java">
                  <xhtml:div>
                     <xhtml:br/>
                     <xhtml:i>...</xhtml:i>
                     <xhtml:br/>IntentFilter filter = new IntentFilter(Intent.ACTION_SHUTDOWN);<xhtml:br/>BroadcastReceiver sReceiver = new ShutDownReceiver();<xhtml:br/>registerReceiver(sReceiver, filter);<xhtml:br/>
                     <xhtml:i>...</xhtml:i>
                     <xhtml:br/>
                     <xhtml:br/>public class ShutdownReceiver extends BroadcastReceiver {<xhtml:div style="margin-left:10px;">@Override<xhtml:br/>public void onReceive(final Context context, final Intent intent) {<xhtml:div style="margin-left:10px;">mainActivity.saveLocalData();<xhtml:br/>mainActivity.stopActivity();</xhtml:div>}</xhtml:div>}</xhtml:div>
               </Example_Code>
               <Body_Text>Because the method does not confirm that the intent action is the expected system intent, any received intent will trigger the shutdown procedure, as shown here:</Body_Text>
               <Example_Code Nature="attack" Language="Java">
                  <xhtml:div>window.location = examplescheme://method?parameter=value</xhtml:div>
               </Example_Code>
               <Body_Text>An attacker can use this behavior to cause a denial of service.</Body_Text>
